title-group.article-title: Twenty years later: Biodiversity of marine symbiotic Siphonostomatoida (Copepoda) off Southern Africa

sec.title: N/A
sec.p: Twenty years later: Biodiversity of marine symbiotic Siphonostomatoida ( Copepoda ) off Southern Africa
SUSAN M DIPPENAAR
Department of Biodiversity, University of Limpopo , South Africa
� susan.dippenaar@ul.ac.za; https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1780-5548

sec.title: Abstract
sec.p: Siphonostomatoida ( Copepoda ) consists of 40 families of symbionts infecting vertebrates (17 families) and invertebrates (23 families) found mostly in marine habitats. In 2004, a list was compiled of all the reported families, genera and species symbiotic with marine fish in Southern African waters. Since this was done 20 years ago, it is necessary to re-evaluate the progress made in 20 years regarding our knowledge of the diversity of marine siphonostomatoids. To assess the current knowledge, the 2004 list was updated with reports published since 2004 as well as with new host and locality records including species with changes in taxonomy. Additionally, species collected but unreported as well as species previously reported but with new hosts and/or localities were also added. Currently reports include 16 families, 75 genera and 234 species. However, amongst these are reports of only two families (3 species) infecting invertebrates. Even though the report includes 71 additional species it still compares poorly with the about 2 274 accepted species, especially regarding species infecting invertebrates. Considering South Africa’s wealth in possible marine host species, examination of more hosts (especially marine teleosts and invertebrates) will definitely result in an increase in the current knowledge about the biodiversity of marine siphonostomatoids off Southern Africa.

sec.title: N/A
sec.p: Key words: Siphonostomatoids , parasitic , vertebrates , invertebrates , oceans

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
A list of reported symbiotic siphonostomatoids from marine fishes of Southern Africa was compiled and published in 2004. At the time only 15 of the 40 families were reported which included only about 172 species (
). Thus, it is necessary to report on our progress regarding the knowledge about the diversity of the marine siphonostomatoids off Southern Africa about 20 years later and provide a more complete assessment of the current knowledge of the diversity of siphonostomatoids.

sec.title: Material and Methods
sec.p: Additionally, hosts caught in the Indian and Atlantic Oceans off South Africa since 2004 were examined for infection by siphonostomatoids. Collected specimens were examined and identified and new records of siphonostomatoids and/or hosts as well as new geographic locations are reported ( Table 2 ).

sec.title: Results and Remarks
sec.p: In the Eudactylinidae , five new species reports collected from elasmobranchs are included, while the family Hyponeoidae is included with one new species report. In the family Kroyeriidae reports of an additional six species are included ( Table 1 ).

Several taxonomic changes are also found in the Lernaeopodidae .
Albionella etmopteri (Yamaguti, 1939) ( Dippenaar 2004 )
was synonymized with
Neoalbionella etmopteri (Yamaguti, 1939)
;
Alella gibbosa van Niekerk & Olivier, 1995
and
A . macrotrachelus (Brian, 1906) ( Dippenaar 2004 )
were both synonymized with
A . pagelli (Krøyer, 1863) ( Dippenaar 2016 )
;
Brachiella dentici Nuñes-Ruivo, 1962
(
) was synonymized with
Parabrachiella dentici (Nuñes-Ruivo, 1962)
;
B . genypteri Capart, 1959
(
) is synonymized with
P . supplicans ( Barnard, 1955 )
;
B . lithognathae Kensley & Grindley, 1973
(
) is a synonymy of
Sparidicola lithognathae (Kensley & Grindley, 1973)
;
B . supplicans Barnard, 1955
(
) is a synonym of
P . supplicans ( Barnard, 1955 )
;
Charopinus bicaudatus (Krøyer, 1837) ( Dippenaar 2004 )
was synonymized with
Pseudocharopinus bicaudatus (Krøyer, 1837)
;
Clavella pagri (Capart, 1959) ( Dippenaar 2004 )
was synonymized with
Clavellotis pagri (Krøyer, 1863)
;
Clavellopsis appendiculata Kirtisinghe, 1950
(
) is a synonym of
Isobrachia appendiculata Heegaard, 1947
;
C . fallax (Heller, 1865) ( Dippenaar 2004 )
was synonymized with
Clavellotis fallax (Heller, 1865)
;
C . hostilis (Heller, 1865) ( Dippenaar 2004 )
was synonymized with
Parabrachiella hostilis (Heller, 1865)
;
Neobrachiella chevreuxii (Beneden, 1891) ( Dippenaar 2004 )
was synonymized with
Parabrachiella chevreuxii (Beneden, 1891)
;
N . insidiosa (Heller, 1865) ( Dippenaar 2004 )
is a synonym of
Parabrachiella insidiosa (Heller, 1865)
;
N . merluccii (Bassett-Smith, 1896) ( Dippenaar 2004 )
a synonymy of
Parabrachiella merluccii (Bassett-Smith, 1896) (WoRMS Editorial Board 2023)
; and
Schistobrachia ramosa (Krøyer, 1863)
is a synonym of
S . kabata Dippenaar, 2016
(
). Additional symbionts reported from hosts belonging to the family Lernaeopodidae (11 species, excluding new combinations) are included ( Table 1 ).

In the family Lernanthropidae fewer taxonomic changes were made with
Lernanthropus trachuri Brian, 1903
(
) being synonymized with
Lernanthropinus caranxi (Hesse, 1878)
;
Lernanthropus ecclesi Kensley & Grindley 1973
(
) a synonymy of
Lernanthropus micropterygis Richiardi, 1884
; and
Lernanthropus petersi Beneden, 1857
(
) synonymized with
Sagum petersi (Beneden, 1857) (WoRMS Editorial Board 2024 )
. No new reports were added.

Furthermore, additional reports are included of symbionts collected from hosts to Pennellidae (eight species), Sphyriidae (nine species) and Trebiidae (one species). Members of Cancerillidae (two species) and Nicotoidae (one species), symbionts of invertebrate hosts, are also included ( Table 1 ). Apart from new species reports, new host or locality reports since 2004 are also included in the table.

Secondly, a table ( Table 2 ) consisting of collected siphonostomatoids from elasmobranchs and teleosts that were not previously reported from South African waters or previously reported species from new hosts or new geographic locations is compiled. Representatives of seven families are included with additional species recorded for Eudactylinidae (six species), Kroyeriidae (two species), Pandaridae (two species) and Sphyriidae (one species) as well as new host and locality reports for representatives of Caligidae , Eudactylinidae , Lernaeopodidae , Pandaridae and Pseudocycnidae .

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Additionally, two families i.e. Cancerillidae (two species of the same genus from brittle stars) and Nicothoidae (one species from an amphipod) are also reported from invertebrate hosts ( Table 1 ). Thus, only two of the possible 23 families infecting invertebrates are reported from Southern Africa which clearly indicates a lack in knowledge regarding the diversity of siphonostomatoids infecting invertebrates from the region.
